value.value: A polymer which is the output of a manufacturing process.

definition.value: Anthropogenic litter which is present in a coastal environment.

Very large objects that are discarded are typically considered "debris", but this term is loosely defined and there are no standard size classifications which can be used to distinguish debris from litter.

value.value: A manufacturing process which includes plastic as one of its specified outputs.

definition.value: Weathering during which plastic is worn or broken down.

value.value: A surface layer which is 1) part of a phreatic zone in contact with a vadose zone and 2) contains interstitial water with a pressure head equal to atmospheric pressure.

definition.value: Soil compaction is a compaction process during which the bulk density of soil increases and/or its porosity decreases due to externally or internally applied loads.
An elevation which inheres in a water table by virture of its vertical distance from a land surface.

While called "depth", this is not the depth of the water table but rather how far it is below a reference plane, usually the soil surface. Thus, this is placed under PATO:elevation which allows for distance above and below a reference point.

value.value: A rate which is characteristic of irradiance by photosynthetically active radiation by virtue of the number of photons received by an irradiated surface over time.

definition.value: Often represented in micromoles of photons associated with photosynthetically active radiation per square meter per second.

value.value: A soil which has a high bulk density and/or a low porosity. A compacted soil has a reduced rate of both water infiltration and drainage
A rate which inheres in a soil percolation process.
Liquid water which 1) flows over land and 2) is not absorbed or retained by the materials if flows over or through.

definition.value: Runoff often gathers debris and solutes from the materials it flows over or through, and often flows into a water body.

value.value: A flux which inheres in photosynthetically active radiation.

definition.value: Often represented in micromoles of photons associated with photosynthetically active radiation per second.
The number of days during which there is precipitation
The threshold at which a day is considered to be a rainy day is highly variable, and determined at the instance level.
The depth of the top part of a soil layer.
The depth of the bottom part of a soil layer.
A water flow process during which water occupies the pores or interstices of a solid or semi-solid material.

value.value: A water infiltration process during which water fills the pore space and interstices of soil.

definition.value: Albedo which inheres in soil.
Soil albedo which inheres in dry soil.
Soil albedo which inheres in moist soil.
This could be axiomatised with PATO:wet, but that isn't likely to map neatly to "moist".

value.value: An ion which is 1) adsorbed onto the surfaces of materials with an opposing charge, 2) are readily displaced by other ions, 3) may be displaced and absorbed by organisms.

definition.value: The exchangeable ion pool is the dominant storage pool for calcium, magnesium, and potassium ions. In soil, exchangeable ions are typically bound to the surface of clay and humus colloids.

value.value: A potassium ion which is capable of ion exchange.
Liquid water which is present in soils as discontinuous volumnes of water in contact with solid and gaseous components of the soil.
A calcium ion which is capable of ion exchange.
A physical quality which inheres in an environmental material by virtue of the material's ability to adsorb exchangeable cations.

definition.value: In soils, these materials include clay and organic matter particles. Soil CEC is measured in millequivalents per 100 grams of soil (meq/100g). A meq is the number of ions which total a specific quantity of electrical charges. Common soil cations include: calcium (Ca++), magnesium (Mg++), potassium (K+), ammonium (NH4+), hydrogen (H+) and sodium (Na+).

value.value: A drainage process during which liquid water is transported away from soil.
A cation exchange capacity which inheres in an environmental material by virtue of the material's ability to adsorb basic exchangeable cations.

definition.value: The basic cation exchange capacity is often expressed as the percentage of the total exchangeable cations which are basic, known as the percentage base saturation. The percentage base saturation is expressed as follows: %BS = [(Ca2+ + Mg2+ + K+)/CEC]  100

value.value: Energy which has been absorbed by an astronomical body or its parts following that body's irradiation by shortwave radiation from a star.

definition.value: Despite the label, this is not a shortwave radiation process, but the energy that is absorbed from one. This term is used to describe, e.g., the energy absorbed from insolation and stored by the Earth. Gross shortwave radiation would also include shortwave radiation reflected back into space by clouds, aerosols, and solid surfaces with high albedo.
A layer that is composed primarily of soil.

value.value: A planned process during which a soil profile is examined and the soil horizons that compose it are described.
Waste water which was converted into an effluent that can be either returned to the water cycle with minimal environmental issues or reused.
Saline water from which minerals have been removed to produce fresh water suitable for human consumption or irrigation.

definition.value: Texture which inheres in soil.

value.value: Soil which is primarily composed of sand with silt and clay in progressively smaller proportions.

Some authorities consider this a soil type, composed of 70-86% of sand, 0-30% of silt and 0-15% of clay. Others consider this a soil material that contains at the upper limit 85 to 90% sand, and the percentage of silt plus 1.5 times the percentage of clay is not less than 15, at the lower limit it contains not less than 70 to 85% sand, and the percentage of silt plus twice the percentage of clay does not exceed 30.

definition.value: Sand which is composed primarily of fine particles.
Thresholds for what particle size is considered "fine" vary by region and authority, as well as the tolerance for proportions of other particle sizes.
Loam which has a high proportion of sand in its composition.

value.value: Some authorities consider sandy loam to be a soil composed of 50-70% sand, 0-50% silt, and 0-20% clay. Others, a soil material that contains either 20% or less clay, with a percentage of silt plus twice the percentage of clay that exceeds 30, and 52% or more sand; or less than 7% clay, less than 50% silt, and between 43% and 52% sand.

definition.value: Loam which has a high proportion of silt in its composition.

value.value: Some authorities consider silt loam to be a soil composed of 20-50% of sand, 74-88% silt and 0-27% of clay.

definition.value: USDA textural classes of soils
Clay loam which has a high proportion of sand in its composition.

value.value: Some authorities consider sandy clay loam to be a soil composed of 45-80% sand, 0-28% silt, and 20-35% clay.

definition.value: Loam which has a high proportion of clay in its composition.

value.value: Some authorities consider clay loam to be a soil composed of 20-45% sand, 15-52% silt, and 27 to 40% clay.

definition.value: Clay loam which has a high proportion of silt in its composition.

value.value: Some authorities consider silty clay loam to be a soil composed of 0-20% of sand, 40-73 of silt and 27-40% of clay.

definition.value: Clay which has a high proportion of sand in its composition.

value.value: Some authorities consider sandy clay to be a soil composed of 45-65% of sand, 0-20% of silt and 35-55% of clay. If the proportion of sand exceeds that of clay, it is unclear whether this is still considered clay (due to other properties) or whether a new class "clay sand" should be created.

definition.value: Clay which has a high proportion of silt in its composition.

value.value: Some authorities consider this a soil composed of 0-20% of sand, 40-60% of silt and 40-60% of clay. If the proportion of silt exceeds that of clay, it is unclear whether this is still considered clay (due to other properties) or whether a new class "clay silt" should be created.

definition.value: A recycling process during which wastewater is treated
A recycling process during which the dissolved mineral salts in water are removed

value.value: A concentration of liquid water in soil arrived at after water which is not retained by the soil has drained away.

The determination of field capacity is variable and multiple methods to do so exist. Even in a given soil, the value of field capacity is variable, but serves as a useful measure of its water-holding capacity. Field capacity is often characterized by measuring water content after wetting a soil profile, covering it (to prevent evaporation) and monitoring the change soil moisture in the profile. Water content when the rate of change is relatively small is indicative of when drainage ceases and is called field capacity, it is also termed drained upper limit (DUL). This measure of field capacity is well-correlated with field capacity determined by applying 33 kPa (or 0.33 bar) of hydraulic head or suction pressure (less in sandy soils) to a portion of soil  and subsequently measuring the bulk water content it retains.Field capacity is usually naturally arrived at 23 days after rain or irrigation in pervious soils of uniform structure and texture.
A concentration of liquid water in soil at or below which a plant will wilt and no longer recover its turgidity when placed in a water saturated atmosphere.

The type of plant and soil are sources of variation for values of this concentration. The physical definition of the wilting point is conventionally measured as the water content at 1,500 kPa (15 bar) of suction pressure, or negative hydraulic head.
Water-holding capacity which inheres in some soil.
An environment that is determined by an axilla skin.
An environment that is determined by a mouth.

label.value: solubility of carbon atom in environmental material

definition.value: The solubility of a carbon atom when measured in environmental material.
